page_analysis.text_content:
Setback considerations

Easements
Some easements affect setbacks i.e., setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line as illustrated in Fig 16 on this page. Easements that affect setbacks are:
• Creek easements
• Public street easements

Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.

Sidewalks
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line. Often, the street easement or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the sidewalk. Fig 16 on this page illustrates this common circumstance and how the setbacks are affected i.e., they must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.

Oddly shaped lots
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious. Fig 17 on page 23 indicates the appropriate site plan for lot shapes about which questions often arise:
• flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• corner lot (Fig 17 B)
• through lot (Fig 17 D)
• wedge-shaped lot (Fig 17 E)
• lot with more than four sides (Fig 17 F & G)

Flag & substandard lots
Fig 17 on page 23 also illustrates examples of setbacks that have been reduced for smaller or oddly shaped lots e.g.,
• the front setback of a flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• the street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide (Fig 17 C)

22

visual_elements.description: Fig 16 Setbacks: easements and sidewalks - Shows a lot layout with easement at top (hatched area), rear yard, buildable area in center, interior side yards on left and right, front yard at bottom, and sidewalk. Includes annotations about setback measurements from easements and lot lines. Contains a key showing symbols for Curb, Lot line, Sidewalk, Required setbacks, Buildable area, and Easement.
Gray box with white text stating 'Note: For information regarding creek easements, contact the Santa Clara Valley Water District'

additional_notes: Page appears to be from a city planning manual with clear text quality
Contains diagram with key/legend for symbols used
Gray informational note box in bottom right corner
cross_references: See section on Lot Size for more information about creek easements
See section on Lot Size for more information about public street easements

qualifiers.text: Often, the street easement or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the sidewalk
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious
for smaller or oddly shaped lots

conditions.text: setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line
they must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk
most public utility easements do not affect setbacks
substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide

logical_relationships.expression: if easements affect setbacks, then setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line
if street easement extends beyond sidewalk, then setbacks must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk
if lots are smaller or oddly shaped, then setbacks may be reduced

execution_sequence.action: Check if street easement extends beyond sidewalk
Evaluate if lot shape affects setback requirements
Apply reduced setbacks for qualifying lots
